"'I thank God through Jesus Christ our Lord.' "'So then with the mind I myself serve the law of God, "'but with the flesh the law of sin.'" And he says, I'm thankful to God. occurrences.text: notes, I'm thankful for this promise. He promised that He would work in us. I'm thankful that He's working in me. I'm thankful that He's working in you. I mentioned this morning that little song, that little chorus that we sing with the kids, that He's still working on me to make me what I ought to be. And I'm thankful for His work in me, and I'm thankful that He's promised to do so. Notice in Ephesians 2, a verse of Scripture that we often are familiar with as we think about verses eight and nine, for by grace are you saved through faith, and that not of yourselves is the gift of God, not of works, lest any man should boast. We find that the thought really doesn't end in verse number nine, it carries into verse number 10, and we think about the truth that He promised to save us. Listen, if He was done with us at the moment of salvation, He'd just go ahead and take us to heaven, amen? And listen, on some days, maybe we'd wonder if it might not be better if we just went ahead and went to heaven, you know? But the reality is that He's doing a work in us. And the purpose of that work in us, according to Romans 8, is that we would be conformed to the image of His dear Son. It's the process of sanctification.

occurrences.text: the Bible says, Romans 6 12, let not sin therefore reign in your mortal body, that you should obey it in the lust thereof, neither yield ye your members as instruments of unrighteousness unto sin, but yield yourselves unto God as those that are alive from the dead, and your members as instruments of righteousness unto God. Because we're saved, we now can yield ourselves unto God. Notice the truth of verse 14, for sin shall not have dominion over you, for you're not under the law, but under grace. And I'm so thankful, notice Romans 8 and verse number 2, where the Bible says, for the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath made me free from the law of sin and death. And I'm no longer bound by the power of sin. We understand that the Bible teaches us that our flesh still has an appetite and still has a desire. The Bible tells us in Galatians 5 that the Spirit is at enmity, or the flesh is at enmity with the Spirit, they're contrary one to the other. And it says, the flesh lusteth against the Spirit and the Spirit against the flesh, and these are contrary the one to the other, so that you cannot do the things that you would. So what's the answer? Walk in the Spirit, that you should not fulfill the lust of the flesh.
